The training rule on licking the lips

original: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: tena samayena buddhaḥ bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,

original: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū oṭṭhanillehakaṁ bhuñjanti …pe…
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyāḥ bhikkhū oṭṭha nillehakam bhuñjanti pe
translated: the monks from the group of six were licking their lips while eating. …

analyzed: na oṭṭha nillehakam bhuñjissāmi iti sikkhā karaṇīyā ati
translated: “‘I will not lick my lips while eating,’ this is how you should train.”
One should not lick one’s lips while eating.

original: Yo anādariyaṁ paṭicca oṭṭhanillehakaṁ bhuñjati, āpatti dukkaṭassa.🔽Anāpatti—
analyzed: yaḥ anādariyam paṭicca oṭṭha nillehakam bhuñjati āpatti dukkaṭassa  anāpatti
translated: If a monk, out of disrespect, licks his lips while eating, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

There is no offense if it is unintentional, if he is not thinking, if he is sick, if his lips are dry, if his lips are chapped, if his lips are cut, if his lips are bleeding, if his lips are swollen, if his lips are split, if he is insane, if he is the first offender.
The fourth training rule is finished.
